text_en: Well, this is the portrait that the series makes of Ana de Mendoza, the princess. Now, Ana, you, expert, explain to us what really happened between the saint and the princess. I was there, of course. Sure, no, I when ... because something I know that many of our readers know, and I'm sure many others can sense, is that I spent a long period of my life immersed in the life of Santa Teresa. I always say that is perhaps my most enduring emotional bond. And when I was immersed 24 hours a day studying the letters of our beloved Santa Teresa, I was always tortured by some blocks of lost correspondence, because we will dedicate an episode to this, but for many reasons, Teresa always said things like, write down on a piece of paper the important things and burn this letter. So a lot of correspondence was lost. And of all the blocks of lost correspondence, for example, which is always alluded to are the letters between her and San Juan de la Cruz, but to me the one that always tortured me the most was her correspondence with Ana de Mendoza. And I say that there must necessarily have been an intense cartel between the two because in 1569 our Ana de Mendoza and her husband called Teresa to found a monastery of friars and a convent of nuns in his ducal villa of Pastrana, Carmen just described. And Teresa did not like the idea of depending on noblewomen to found her convents with a system of rents because, logically, she knew that she would lose a lot of autonomy and that her ideology of poverty and contemplation clashed with the airs of grandeur of those noblewomen. Imagine the Chapines and the discalced Carmelites. That is, it could not work. But, of course, St. Teresa also knew perfectly well that with a system of alms it was almost impossible to ensure the livelihood of her nuns, which was what concerned her most in the world. Then, before the fateful date of 1569, which is when the break between the two occurs and now we will explain why, Teres actually had already known closely to a relative, Diana de Mendoza, in another foundation of a convent in Malagon.
